Memory bandwidth bordering the insanity.On benchmarks it is not compared to other processors, it is compared to GPUs.Oh and all Xeons aren't made to work alone, but are heavily optimized to work in group with other Xeons.GeForce GTX 1080 Ti Graphics Card3584 cores.And this beast is used for games.Of course it can be used also for science, there is indeed a well documented API, though it is marketed for gaming.Ever wondered if you canOr a kind of peripheral that sorts a limited array ofFPGAStratix 10 - OverviewIntel Altera FPGAs, are as close you can get to nanometer programmable matter.Field Programmable Gate Array is a fancy way to say that everything inside that big fat black chip is completely under your control.Want to stuff in 8 big CPUs or 256 adder cores? Within minutes you can try both.They can emulate any circuit at high speeds, manage hundreds of lines and emulate high speed peripherals like HDMI or USB3.One core application is to elaborate video filters in real time with no delay at all.There are even cheap ones starting at about 20 bucks.Direct brain to computer interfacesIn the comments I heard complains like, “hey commercial things can't be the most advanced thing, right?”.And they are right.Because research is ongoing to command computers with just your brain!The headgear in the image, I still haven't got a chance to use, but trying lesser capable versions, they do work and with minimal training anybody can drive a small robot with thoughts.Homepage - EmotivWith anybody I mean I've tested it on more than 150 people, with less than 5 minutes of training. We cannot know everything with absolute precision because quantum mechanics does not let us do so.Heisenberg developed this in 1927As you can see in the image above, there is always a set of possible values for position (blue) and momentum (red). It is not an exact value, only a range of possible values due to the uncertainty principle.The range of values can also change. If one value is measured more accurately, the other is measured less accurately (or not measured at all). You can see this here. As the accuracy of the measurement of the position goes up (the blue has a higher peak), the accuracy of the measurement of the momentum goes down (the red has a lower peak). Vice versa, as the accuracy of momentum goes up, the accuracy of position goes down. This shows the inverse relationship between position and momentum, given in the equation,Sources:

Answer: No, it’s not anything like that. Not an engineering shortcoming in any way. Events at the quantum scale simply include a non-determinism that is innate to reality. At the large scale of our everyday lives the phenomena that we see happening around us involve extremely large numbers of fundamental events, and the “random noise” associated with this non-determinism averages out. The randomness becomNo, it’s not anything like that. Not an engineering shortcoming in any way. Events at the quantum scale simply include a non-determinism that is innate to reality. At the large scale of our everyday lives the phenomena that we see happening around us involve extremely large numbers of fundamental events, and the “random noise” associated with this non-determinism averages out. The randomness becomes tiny compared to the scale our perception is sensitive to, so we don’t see it or notice it in any way. It was only when we started doing particular experiments that involves small quanta count that these effects became visible to us.If you just think about it for a minute, something of this sort had to happen somewhere in physics. We have free will. People actually argue over that - some people claim we don’t, but I consider it to be a self-evident fact. We are self-aware beings and we have free will. In order for that free will to manifest in physical reality, there had to be something in physics that doesn’t flow from a well-defined and demonstrable cause-and effect relationship. The whole excursion that physicists took into the idea of a “clockwork universe” where the entire future and past could be determined from a “now snapshot” was really folly all along - we should have known better.Now, let me try to answer your question. Why is there uncertainty? First thing to understand is that quantum theory tells us that the state of any system at any given time is specified by a “wave function,” and that this wave function contains absolutely everything that can be known about the system. There is no “more complete” specification - that’s it.Next, we can’t actually measure or observe the wave function itself. It’s “beyond our reach.” But all of the things we can measure are related to that wave function in a probabilistic way. In special cases, when the wave function is already “compatible” with the quantity you wish to measure, it will give you a precise prediction. But most of the time the wave function is not compatible with your observable - in that case the wave function allows you to calculate a set (possibly infinite) of possible outcomes along with the probability that you will get each one as the result of your measurement.The “clockwork universe” of the 1800’s relied upon being able to measure pairs of quantities - the number of such pairs depends on the complexity of your system. In classical mechanics these are referred to as “coordinates” and “conjugate momenta.” In order to make a full prediction of the future state of a classical system, you need all of the coordinate and momentum values associated with your system - you can use these as initial conditions in the differential equations of motion a...

Answer: I go to North Korea annually to study about life for average people. In the DPRK there are classes of people who live quite different lives but for most all but the elites life is hard.Pyongyang is atypical of the country as a whole. The apartments are better, transportation is better and access to consumer goods is much better. Electricity and running water can be a problem in the capital butI go to North Korea annually to study about life for average people. In the DPRK there are classes of people who live quite different lives but for most all but the elites life is hard.Pyongyang is atypical of the country as a whole. The apartments are better, transportation is better and access to consumer goods is much better. Electricity and running water can be a problem in the capital butApartments in PyongyangApartments in PyongyangOther cities begin to decline from there. In Nampo I have seen people hauling water up to apartments from a communal well and in Pyongsong I watched people pump water up via hoses outside to their apartments. Elevators in older buildings no longer work. Chongjin, Kaesong, and parts of Hamhung are run down with little or no maintenance. Cardboard can be seen in windows. Electricity there is a problem as well.Hauling water in NampoHauling water in NampoApartments in ChongjinApartments in ChongjinApartments in HamhungApartments in HamhungApartments in WonsanApartments in WonsanOverall in the country cooking oil is one of the most precious commodities. Last month I watched a neighborhood group cutting up a large amount of cooking oil into liter bottles being ever so careful. I have watched as baggage comes into the Sunnan airport and cooking oil is leaking from bags and boxes. Oil, salt and sugar are rare.The major cities outside Pyongyang will vary in food availability. I have seen times of plenty and little. Food is being dried on balconies in cities. You see squid drying on clotheslines as well as corn and peppers.The regional towns vary widely. Sariwon is generally nice and Anju is not as good. As you get into these towns that is where you see where most people live - smaller towns, villages and the countryside.Sariwon, an agricultural townSariwon, an agricultural townAnju - poor apartments and bad roads.Anju - poor apartments and bad roads.In the countryside you see small traditional Korean homes. Older ones are in disrepair and the newer ones are well kept.Rural homes.Those in these rural homesCorn on rural homesCorn on rural homesLife itself is hard and I mean that physical labor is often the way to do anything. The harvest is done by hand and even factories and office workers will often be required in the fall to help with the harvest.Field work last month near Sariwon.Field work last month near Sariwon.Road labor is much the same way. I have seen older people out breaking rocks to fill in potholes of the roads and highways. I have seen younger people digging drainage ditches (younger teens) and work brigades digging during a typhoon.Working on the Youth HighwayWorking on the Youth HighwayWith transportation shortages the servi-cha is the way to get around. You pay a driver to take you to the next town, otherwise you use bus #11 - walking (Korean joke).Servi-cha in Kumya North KoreaServi-cha in Kumya North KoreaBicycles are really what is relied upon and vital.Agricultural workers' bicyclesAgricultural workers' bicyclesBicycle repair on the road - many bike shops are no more than a man with a kit and a pump.Bicycle repair on the road - many bike shops are no more than a man with a kit and a pump.With shortages of coal to heat and cook your food, chronic food shortages, long distances to walk, labor, the sheer number of hours spent on food preservation - everything just to survive leads to a hard life.Coal for apartment heating and cooking.Coal for apartment heating and cooking.Food storage area in a homeFood storage area in a homeWe take for granted many modern conveniences that are unknown in the DPRK. Think of a cash economy with doing virtually everything manually. That is the reality for most North Koreans.

They can see everything inside of you all at once. They can see inside of anything. They can reach in and remove everything from inside a safe without ever opening it. They can remove the yolk from an egg without cracking it open. They can pop in and out of ‘existence’ at their leisure.This is all based on what it would be like if we could interact with beings that lived in 2-dimensions and applying it one dimension up. For example if you draw a square on a piece of paper and a dot outside of it. The dot is a 2-dimensional being and the square is its home. The dot can’t see inside the square because the sides are in the way. But you and I peering down from the third dimension can see what’s inside just by looking at the paper.My first introduction to understanding the fourth dimension, and the foundation of this answer, comes from the book Flatland by Edwin Abbott written in 1884. The first half is a little dry as he talks about the social hierarchy of Flatland but if you stick with it you’ll be rewarded with a better understanding of spacial dimensions.
